item.title: Team 4 - Justice Reform Expert
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The mid-term evaluation of 3 projects (Drugs and Crime, Anti-corruption and Justice) will provide the EU and other partners with an assessment of the projects' performance and recommendations on how to improve the intervention to achieve expected goals and outcomes taking into account problems and opportunities.

Team 4 - Justice Reform Expert (25 working days)

  • University Degree (Academic level) in Law, Political Science or a relevant, directly related discipline, or equivalent
  • Professional experience as programme manager/expert in the Justice sector, or equivalent
  • Effective verbal and written communication skills and ability to write reports in a clear and concise manner in English
  • Experience in Sub-Saharan Africa;
  • Minimum of 3 years' experience in project management and evaluation of development project in complex political environments
  • At least 6 years of professional experience as programme manager/expert in the Rule of Law, Justice Sector Reform, Police or Prison reform, or equivalent
  • Experience with capacity development projects as per guidance provided by the “EU backbone strategy” (http://ec.europa.eu/development/icenter/repository/backbone_strategy_technical_cooperation_en.pdf) and the “Guidelines on "Making technical cooperation more effective”“ (http://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/how/ensure-aideffectiveness/ documents/guidelinesontcfinaleen.pdf).
  • Familiarity with international standards and methods regarding justice delivery and justice sector reform
  • Highly developed interpersonal skills to relate to counterparts on all levels of hierarchy
  • IT literate, very good data-processing knowledge, and of office automation software
  • Experience in communication, negotiation and dialogue at high level

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to benjamin_symonds@dai.com

item.title: Senior Expert II- Capacity Building and Institutional Development
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
The global objective is to assess and continually improve the quality of EU assistance projects in order to support better Mozambique’s development efforts. There are 2 Key experts allocated 39 working days each, with an additional 10 to be allocated to the Expert acting as Team Leader.

It is required that at least one of the experts has team leader experience combined with a very good experience in evaluations, as he/she will be the team leader.

Senior Expert II- Capacity Building and Institutional Development

  • Degree in economics, law, development studies, public administration, ICT engineering or equivalent.
  • A minimum of 12 years of professional experience in development cooperation.

Specific professional experience in:

  • evaluation of learning and training interventions,
  • monitoring and evaluation of capacity development projects and programmes,
  • cost-benefit analysis of programmes,
  • Experience in performance management systems, organisational and institutional capacity assessment,
  • Experience in conducting evaluations of EU funded projects is an advantage.
  • Excellent management, drafting and communication skills in English,
  • Basic Portuguese for reading reports and day to day communication.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to benjamin_symonds@dai.com

item.title: Expert en Processus Electoraux (Cat. I)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
Le projet a comme objectif l’appui du Gouvernement et de la CENI dans la préparation des élections du Président de l’Union et des Gouverneur des îles autonomes, afin de garantir le droit de vote a tous les citoyens comoriens.

Le projet a comme objectif aussi identifier les modalités les plus adaptées et les moyens techniques et financiers qui permettront au Gouvernement de l’Union des Comores et a la CENI de réviser et de compléter le fichier électoral en prévision des scrutins de 2015/2016, en conformité avec les dispositions du code électoral en vigueur et les recommandations des missions d’observation électorale déployées lors des scrutins du 25 janvier et 22 février 2015.

Expert en Processus Electoraux (cat. I)

Niveau académique master (BAC+5) ou 14 ans d’expérience dans des domaines liés à la gouvernance.

12 ans d’expérience professionnelle, dont au moins 4 ans d’expérience dans le domaine électoral (préférablement expérience précédente dans la révision des listes électorales).

Expérience précédent comme chef d’équipe sur des projets similaires à l’international.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to nicte_garcia-soria@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.description:
The objective is to recruit assessors to assist the Contracting Authority in the selection of the best proposals received under “Pro-Resilience Action (PRO-ACT): building resilience through crisis prevention and post-crisis response strategy” and to achieve a high-quality, complete and coherent selection process of projects in line with the criteria set in the Guidelines for applicants.

Project duration: 180 days

Assessors – Experience in Rural Development/Food Security in Sub-Saharan Africa (25 working days per expert)

  • Master’s Degree in relevant subject.
  • At least 10 years’ experience gained in sectors 9 and 10: Rural Development and Food Security.
  • At least 6 years’ experience in Sub-Saharan Africa.
  • Experience participating in the selection of grant recipients as an assessor on behalf of a national authorising officer or an international organisation is essential.
  • Work experience in post-conflict areas, in particular in fragile states.
  • Very good knowledge of project cycle management and of EU grants contract procedures.
  • Work experience in South Sudan is an asset.
  • Fluent in English

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to benjamin_symonds@dai.com

item.title: Expert Economiste ou Agroéconomiste (catégorie I)
item.author: Penny Buckle
item.description:
L’étude a mener contribue par ses conseils a l’amélioration durable de la compétitivité (quantitative et qualitative) de la filière bananière camerounaise, en appuyant des activités qui favorisent la rentabilité sur le marché mondial, dans le strict respect des normes sociales et environnementales de la production, tout en améliorant la balance commerciale du pays.

Duree: 3 mois

Expert Economiste ou Agroéconomiste (catégorie I)

*Qualifications *:

Economiste ou équivalent en gestion ou commerce, ayant une expertise dans l’analyse de filière et l’étude de marches du secteur agro-alimentaire (école ou universitaire, minimum BAC+5)

Expérience professionnelle:

  • Au moins 12 ans dans les études de marche des filières (agricoles) et les domaines du marketing et du commerce international.
  • Au moins 6 ans d’expérience professionnelle en diagnostic et conseil en économie ou gestion des filières agro-alimentaires, dont une filière fruit ou légume
  • Connaissances suffisantes des normes alimentaires et phytosanitaires régissant l’importation de bananes en Europe
  • Expérience technique ou juridique sur les règles et procédures commerciales, accords commerciaux, instruments de facilitation du commerce, politique commerciale.
  • Bonne connaissance des stratégies commerciales et marketing dans le domaine des produits agricoles et avoir une bonne connaissance des circuits de commercialisation des produits agricoles, particulièrement d’Afrique.
  • Expérience dans la conduite et la rédaction de diagnostics et de plans d’action et de cahier de charges.
  • Une bonne capacité de communication est indispensable.
  • Bonne maitrise d’anglais et français.
  • Préférable d’avoir une bonne connaissance de langue allemande.

If you meet the requirements and would be interested in applying for this role please email your CV in EC format to Veronica_hernandez-castilla@dai.com

WE ARE ONLY ABLE TO RESPOND TO CANDIDATES WHO MEET THE SPECIFICATIONS

item.title: AWP 2 Projects Review
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
The Beyond WTO Program (B-WTO) was developed in response to a request from the Government of Vietnam (GoV) for donor support to help with managing economic integration and the transition to a market economy following WTO accession. The B-WTO goal is “to strengthen government’s capacity to manage the integration of Vietnam into the global economy and the transition of Vietnam to a socialist market economy”. The immediate objective is “implementation of priority policy actions from the GoV’s Action Plan to enhance Vietnam’s capacity to sustain pro-poor growth (GAP)”.

The remit of this project was a review of the 2nd annual work plan’s implementation (AWP2) of Phase 2 of the B-WTO in May 2013. The objectives of the review were to:

  • Evaluate the project implementation performance and project results relative to the logical framework targets and evaluation criteria.
  • Evaluate the results achieved at the Component and Program’s level according to the Monitoring and Evaluation (M&E) framework of the Program.
  • Identify lessons learned from implementation, make recommendations for the remaining duration of the program and the Independent Completion Report process.

item.title: Health Program M&E
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.

item.title: Program 2013 Performance and Quality Mapping Exercise
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: AusAID’s PNG Program is looking to improve its performance and quality (P&Q) standards and systems. The purpose of this project was to map the PNG Program’s current P&Q capacity and systems, to address the risk of AusAID being unable to demonstrate results for its increased investments in PNG over the next four years. Over the last several years, the PNG Program has undertaken a number of M&E assessments and reviews which have identified key strengths and challenges within the program. This project was intended to pick up where these assessments left off. Through a desk review and consultations with sector teams, the Review Team were to distil key P&Q risks and issues for the PNG Program. The Review Team’s brief included the provision of recommendations on priority activities to support sector approaches to M&E, strengthen the Program’s ability to collect evidence, provide critical analysis and report on results.

item.title: Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
AusAID required a consultant to assist with the development and finalisation of its Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework. Development of a humanitarian monitoring and evaluation framework is a key commitment outlined in AusAID’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy (HAP) and its associated Implementation Plan. In line with the agency focus on results reporting, the HAP and HAP Implementation Plan commit AusAID to develop a monitoring and evaluation framework to support the initial performance assessment framework contained within the HAP and AusAID annual reporting under the Comprehensive Aid Policy Framework.

The key objective of this assignment was to build the Humanitarian program’s capacity for monitoring and reporting results by:

  • In consultation with AusAID’s Humanitarian team, redraft and finalise the Humanitarian Performance Assessment Framework, to ensure it provides a platform to:
  • Track implementation of key commitments in Australia’s 2011 Humanitarian Action Policy; and,
  • Establish a set of measurable humanitarian performance indicators (in addition to the two CAPF indicators) to enable AusAID to track achievements, lessons learned and to report on the results achieved from AusAID’s humanitarian work.

item.title: Review of Pacific Forum Compact Reporting
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description: The purpose of the assignment was to examine country views of aid effectiveness and regional organisations expressed through Forum Compact reporting, particularly peer review of Forum Island Countries’ national development plan processes. The services provided included the preparation of a think piece which outlines key aid effectiveness issues arising from country reporting under the Compact reporting and discusses options for addressing these issues.

item.title: Health Program M&E Specialist
item.author: Bryan Schuetz
item.description:
In partnership with the Ministry of Health (MoH), the Australian Government is scoping and piloting a new approach to engagement in the health sector in Timor-Leste. The program approach is innovative in several respects. Key program features are: a systems perspective; joint program oversight by MoH and Australian Government; an emphasis on capacity facilitation through coaching rather than an over-reliance on more traditional technical assistance approaches; ongoing processes of joint intervention design throughout implementation; and rapid cycles of evidence-informed adaptation. These will require significant investments in interactive, exploratory, and rigorous monitoring and evaluation, requiring support from an M&E Specialist that is comfortable with non-traditional M&E approaches.

The Health Program M&E Specialist worked with the Australian Government Timor-Leste Health Team to design an M&E system for Australia’s support to the health sector, that is aligned with the Ministry of Health’s draft Sector M&E Framework and consistent with Australian Aid Program M&E Standards. The primary purpose of the M&E System will be to support strategic management and ongoing improvement of the Australian Government - MoH partnership in the health sector.
